job_title: Motor Vehicle Operator in Amherst, NY
pros: Lots of breaks. Free boots and safety glasses.
cons: Management is terrible. Not a multicultural accepting department. Mandatory over time, is not mandatory. Job performance reviews are based on how much OT workers work. All general laborers and management are promoted "within". Generally, cleaning facilities department. Current management has no career outside of UB. Because of the hiring for this department, there is zero organization, or logistics to the seasonal work. Nepotism serves all the individuals that are promoted to supervisor or higher - promotion is not based on ability or experience of work. Hostile work environment. Union doesn't serve to better the workers or the quality of life, or work environment, suggest not paying the dues. This place has almost no equipment to operate, all MVO's are hired for snow work in winter with light duty CDL dump trucks. The snow removal equipment is sub par for a campus of its size, - outdated and beat up equipment. In summer all snow loaders are returned to lease and MVO's cut grass. Grass equipment is old, and heavily used. For landscaping, not many usable correct tools. Things are not done properly, a lot of wasted time and money. Benefits are mediocre. At 36,000k with inflation, its a poverty level job.

review_title: Adjunct Instructor at School of Management
pros: This is the highest paying adjunct teaching position in Western New York. Paperwork at the beginning of the appointment is minimal and health insurance is quite generous. We are allowed to teach both grad and undergrad students in the business school and both types are extremely smart. This makes our job much easier than for those in other colleges in this region. The textbook-related support through the department secretary helps the preparation process. Classrooms are quite equipped to handle a laptop per student which is the type of method I prefer.
cons: The biggest con about this employer as far as my position goes is that we are not given graders (at least not in School of Management). So many of us have to compromise by forcing team-based activities in order to take up reduced grading loads which can be unfair to some students who are stuck in lousy teams. Another negative point is the lack of sufficient amount of parking facilities, especially near School of Management. WiFi in and around classrooms are astonishingly still not strong enough to handle connections from all students which can hurt during essential in-class exercises. These are of course, in no way, deal breakers for accepting a position at this institution.

review_title: Awesome part-time working environment for a student
pros:
I worked for around 3 years as a part-time student assistant for the Enterprise Infrastructure Services department of CIT.  There wasn't a large work load, and we were allowed to work on schoolwork when we weren't busy.  This, along with the extremely flexible scheduling, made this job an amazing asset while pursuing my BS/MS.

The staff and coworkers I met while working there were really nice, intelligent people.  Management was always accomodating and willing to listen to my concerns.  Opportunities were also available to increase the workload, and proactive employees were generally given slightly higher pay (and usually an offer for a full-time position on graduation)
cons: If you aren't proactive in searching for work and either get lazy or focus too much on doing homework, then pay raises are very rare.  Although, as someone who needed plenty of time for homework, this was a more than acceptable tradeoff.  There are opportunities to get a larger workload and hence a bigger pay, but you must be proactive in looking for new ways you can assist the staff

pros:
My area is very flexible with work time start/end and family friendly. 
Vacation/sick/personal time is accrued at a fair rate. 
There are great discounts to take advantage of as the U is quite large and gets good deals.
Life insurance, health insurance, cell phone discounts, vacation time off, many events if you want to be really involved. pros: after visiting the campus, i can tell you this college is the biggest one i've been to. i enjoyed the presentation and enthusiasm from the first part of my tour, but was very disappointed in the actual tour. i wish there was more one on one time to see something specific to my field, but it was too hard because we had to see the whole campus.

review_title: Decent school and place to work at
job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Buffalo, NY
pros: The experience at UB depends on the department and the PI you work for. Overall it was a pretty good place to work at. My work schedule was very flexible time. I travelled two to three time a year based on research output to conferences. Most lab personals and PIs were nice and helpful in the department I was in. My department was also diverse (minority and women). New professors are also being hired. My PI provided us with nice opportunities to get grant money. She was quite knowledgeable about the system. I did publish several manuscripts. Health insurance was pretty good.
cons:
My PI was difficult to work with. Some were super old. 
Work schedule is long but that is typical for any graduate student wanting to publish
Besides the weather of Buffalo. I didn't have aby major issues

review_title: A large organization that's good to work for but not without its challenges.
job_title: Senior Programmer/Analyst in East Amherst, NY
pros: The teams and other employees you work with, for the most part, are enthusiastic about their work and jobs. The university is a community unto itself and offers almost everything you'd expect to find in a small town but with a significant international/melting-pot atmosphere. During the late spring semester, for instance, there's a farmer's market outside one of the libraries. Student groups offer movies that range from Hollywood to small art films. The new president's "UB2020" vision promises to raise the university to a higher level.
cons: Management is largely reactive and slow to adopt change. Management style is "old school": very much top-down, worker-bee. There doesn't seem to be a lot of respect for in-house expertise/talent; the vast majority of solutions are consultant or vendor delivered.

job_title: Senior Staff Associate in Buffalo, NY
pros: Why wouldn't you want to work at a school where the students are hard workers, the faculty care about their school, students and culture and the staff are dedicated and knowledgeable?  The University at Buffalo is extremely diverse and rich with interesting, hardworking people.  I have hardly had an unanswered email from a staff or faculty member or alum when I have asked for advice or to collaborate.
cons: Parking stinks. Pretty liberal environment, but it is a college, so that is to be expected.

review_title: A place that rewards doing the least amount of work possible. Bloated, stuck in the past, and risk-averse to a fault.
pros: Tenure system for ALL professional employees, benefits package is 2x private sector for same job, pension for employees with 20/30+ years of service. Nearly impossible to get fired.
cons: Tenure system and forgiving HR ensures that firings are a rare event, as a result openings are few and far between and little room for advancement. "Spend it or loose it" budgets incentivize wasting money left and right, especially at the end of the fiscal year. As a government agency, isn't affected by market forces and treats tax dollars like they are burning a hole in their pocket.

review_title: SUNY Buffalo has a strong chemistry research program
job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Buffalo, NY
pros: Strong faculty student interactions. Additionally, the professors are always very supportive of their students. The graduation rate is high and a PhD takes about 5.5 years.
cons: The support for research is terrible. The people in charge of analytical instruments rarely show up for work and when they do, it is for only four hours or so. They also provide little assistance when you struggle to obtain analytical data. The glassblower is also useless as he refuses to repair any glassware you submit. He also does not show up for work. The department is understaffed and for some reason staff can obtain tenure. This has crushed the support system because some tenured staff are overpaid, lazy, and very difficult to get rid of.

review_title: Nice, but snowy place to work
pros: The pay is good for a postdoc, and with a large faculty there is plenty of opportunity for collaboration.  It gave me a chance to continue and finish up some projects that I began in graduate school.  This aspect I found to be very useful, as it allowed me t o ramp up to productivity quite quickly while also starting some new projects that would take awhile before coming to fruition.
cons: Just like any postdoc, it's a temporary position, so you should begin with an end in mind.  You're a bit isolated geographically, so inter-university collaboration may be minimal.  It snows a lot too, so be prepared for it.

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Buffalo, NY
pros: Great health benefits, tuition covered and stipend when being a teaching assistant.
cons: People in charge of health insurance don't do their jobs, I've gone without insurance for a month or more before because they could not or would not do their job well enough to help me/ did not direct me to the correct person to talk to.

job_title: Graduate Teaching Assistant in Buffalo, NY
pros: The grad school is awesome. The chemistry department that I work in is has approximately 150 graduate students. The compensation that the grad students get is pretty good for a place like Buffalo, where the expenses are pretty low compared to big cities.
cons: The climate is definitely the worst thing about Buffalo. Long winters and short summers. The compensation for the professors is quite low, because its a state university. Because of this they are not able to retain talented scientists from being nicked by other big universities.

review_title: Better than nothing, but needs serious improvement.
pros: Getting tuition paid for.  Ability to support your education plans and get beginning experience teaching (though this is a matter of luck of the draw).
cons: Complete luck of the draw with professors - you will either be completely overworked by someone who abuses their power and does nothing but manage, or you will be given small supervised tasks that are boring and do nothing to enhance your career growth and could be assigned to someone completely untrained in your field.

review_title: Flagship university in a growing economy
job_title: Director of Strategic Digital Communications in Buffalo, NY
pros: UB is the largest university in Western New York. With three campuses (North, Main Street and Downtown), it has several unique personalities. The faculty and staff are dedicated not only to their colleagues and the students, but also to the local communities. There's an excellent mix of local people and people from outside the area (national and international). The university has been, for several years, working with a long term vision to improve both itself and WNY on a number of levels.
cons: It's really big: bureaucracy at an organization this large is difficult to escape. Change can be slow. Depending on the office or division, there may be limited opportunities for advancement.

job_title: Director of Development in Buffalo, NY
pros: Benefits, independent working environment, opportunity to serve the better good
cons: No real direction from senior Management and Dean on direction they needed me to go.  I created my own objectives and worked hard to meet my goals.

pros: Excellent colleagues and wonderful but pricey Union and Health benefits.
cons: For every hour in the classroom with the students, there is at least 1 - 2 hours of planning and grading as well as meeting with students. Humanities Adjuncts are only paid for hours IN the CLASSROOM.  We are paid absolutely NOTHING for preparing lessons, grading, or meeting with students. Adjuncts are not paid a living wage.

pros: Doing research is a good way to apply knowledge while attending the school to learn new knowledge. The professors here are nice and experienced. They are always ready to help students inside or outside the classroom.
cons: The co-relation of the school with the industry is too limited so that students do not have enough access to industry and do the internship during the regular semester which i think is the most important course in Chemical Engineering major.

review_title: Working for the state is great is you don't expect high pay
pros: Relaxed working environment - there are hardly any crucial deadlines, and you can go home and not have to think about work.  The benefits for UUP members are still pretty great.  You will not find better vacation time or retirement benefits elsewhere.
cons: Being a union shop has its downside too, and that is that talented employees cannot earn more, and poor employees can not be let go.  The recently approved contract promises lower wages and worse benefits.

job_title: Student Assistant in East Amherst, NY
pros: They are very understanding and great to work for.
cons: It's a great place to work but not the pay is not great if you're a student.  Students are definitely underpaid and would earn so much more if they worked in different locations.  I feel like the university takes advantage of students working on campus who are not eligible for a workstudy grant.  Even workstudy students get paid more than student assistants who don't qualify for the grant.  I think it's a different story for graduate students, but undergraduates definitely get the worst pay.

pros: One of the pros of the program was that I was able to meet with a lot of distinguished research professors, who taught invaluable skills in areas of economic research. The people were very friendly and always happy to assist you in any difficult task you might have on your hands.
cons: I can't really think of any cons during my experience. So I guess I will continue to write here in order to meet this twenty words minimum requirement for Glassdoor.

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Buffalo, NY
pros: The opportunities to experience the different dimensions of research, both qualitative and quantitative, in a real, research-oriented setting are excellent. The desire to do good, quality research is strong and the opportunities to share/collaborate with other researchers is readily available.
cons: As a State university, the salary opportunity is limited. Additionally, the opportunities to advance from graduate student to faculty position are not readily available as often the desire is to pull new ideas from outside.

pros: Easy parking. Decent benefits. Access to many seminars and speakers. Most staff are very helpful. Compensation is on par with other institutions.
cons: Very low morale. Departments are dysfunctional. There seems to be no oversight over managers. Bad behavior is rewarded, while hardworking employees tend to be punished. Even though employees earn a lot of vacation many managers will not let them use vacations. Most researchers don't have money to take on new students and employees.  Some managers have tried to force employees to work holidays, work overtime with no pay, and ask employees inappropriate questions.

pros: It's a friendly place and does not expect a lot from its employees. So it's a good place to start if you are beginner like me.
cons: As mentioned on the Pros, since SUNY Buffalo doesn't expect a lot, there is not a lot of growth opportunity and hence it might get in your way once you are past that beginner phase.

pros: flexible hours, some excellent supervisors. clear raise schedule, quality training, easy workload
cons: some employees are typical state workers, the kind who are in a state position because they are not skilled enough or have enough ambition to make it in the private sector. Difficult to work for these types of people because they usually only do the bare minimum.

review_title: Great environment, wonderful workforce and outstanding benefits in an intellectually and culturally challenging site.
pros: The staff and resources are all top drawer. The pay grade was good and as a state job, benefits, with union support, were excellent. The major portion of my work life was spent with the University. I made many life-long friends.
cons: I felt the mission/direction of such a large institution would be, from year to year, a little misinformed or mis-communicated. While the administration tried hard to brand the institution as a leading and growing research center the way that message played out was sometimes difficult.

pros: The place has good benefits (depending on union contract negotiations). A mix of project work and system upkeep. A place where a jack of all trades can easily fit in. Only need to put in about 50% effort to get by if that's your thing.
cons: Low pay. Organizational structure changes often. Departments come and go based on latest revision of management. As more are union positions, give too many people the opportunity to slack without any recourse.

review_title: A good place to start or end a career.
job_title: Instructional Support Associate in Buffalo, NY
pros: At the time, UB had great benefits and a very good work life balance. Working at UB was not going to make you wealthy, but it was a nice change from the rat race of corporate America. The people are generally very friendly.
cons: Since permanent appointment (tenure) is available for professional staff, may of the people working in technology are "behind the times"  and as a result, never leave UB. This makes advancement very difficult.

review_title: if you make it in, you've got a job for a while
pros: connected to the state, which means that eventually there's some sort of pension
cons: very large so the bureaucracy can be pretty messy. Also, they tend to move you around to different departments which can be difficult. Often work gets backed up as well, so you often have to pick up the slack of other people

review_title: CIT Helpdesk Position, Great College Job!
pros: Great part time position for UB students at the CIT Helpd esk, great staff and great salary.  The hours are very flexible because of the business hours that we are open.  It is also a great resume builder, I have been offered jobs after college that I would never have received if it was not for this position.
cons: For a student assistant position in the helpdesk, nothing really.

pros: UB has very strong systems and leadership which provide a foundation upon which you can teach wonderful students with autonomy, be treated as a professional, enjoy significant diversity, receive the best benefits, and have the opportunity to grow and learn in your field.
cons: I can not come up with a single downside.  My wish is to be full time at UB.  I have taught at 5 different colleges or universities, and UB has the best students and the best administrative and support systems in place.

review_title: Intersting and thought envoking place of employment, Inspires and pushes creativity
pros: You get to be part of amazing engineering projects that are completely new and innovative. Never a boring moment. Also fmaily oriented place where everyone is willing to help. Everyone is an expert in there respective fields, so a wide variey of colaborative minds are all around you.
cons: WIll test working knowledge and that of unforseen paths of research. You may start down one path in reaching a goal and find nineteen others to go down. However so is the field of research.

pros: Academic environment was a great atmosphere. Department allowed freedom of ideas and supported research in any justifiable field. Screw Flanders.
cons: Salary was quite low, even for Buffalo. So low in fact that it was necessary to take additional student loans to cover basic living expenses.

pros: Some of the best and brightest people to work with. Lots of opportunities to interact with people from academia as well as industry.
cons: Pay is slightly below average and the weather is a huge downer. Apartment from your research group, not much interaction on a daily basis with other people in the department.

review_title: The place has great potential but sets the bar too low
pros: Great compensation and benefits, friendly environment, I have never had an issue where I was not able to take time off to attend to personal matters
cons: Unfair treatment, people that do nothing receive the same compensation as those that work hard. The administration allows too many students to slip through the cracks which then gives the university a bad reputation

pros:
- benefits (health / dental / eye insurance), great retirement, plentiful vacation and sick days, tuition assistance
- very little stress
- short commute if you live near Amherst
- interesting projects and new technologies
cons:
- very little promotional opportunities
- starting pay is low for it workers
- high turnover rate in it
- more support work rather than project work
- currently no telecommute opportunities

pros: Easy job and fun environment. I was working as a developer for software applications and was in charge of developing software that'll be used in admission decisions.
cons: Work wasn't all that great but considering the fact that it is for internal use in the department it was okay for the pay I was getting over there.

pros: UB has a 2020 vision. The CSE department grows by adding 2-3 faculty every year. Most of these scholars hold NSF etc. grants. There is really a good opportunity for academia here. Buffalo is a great place in summer.
cons: Far from big cities. Buffalo is a freezing place in winter. Rankings does not reflect the current situation I think.

review_title: Nice working environment and flexible working hours
job_title: Graduate Teaching Assistant in New York, NY
pros: I was working back at a TA and the whole experience was great, the administrative staff is always friendly and efficient. I don't even have to worry about a thing and they have already finished all paperwork for you. And you have direct communication channel with you boss, so you work closely with him/her.
cons: Working hours is pretty high and pressure from students are intensive as well.

review_title: Dynamic environment but tons of bureaucracy
job_title: Scientific Resource Manager in Buffalo, NY
pros: Love the dynamic nature of the Academic environment, exciting to be a part of discovery based research, comprehensive health care, vacation/sick leave package.
cons:
Processes are slow moving because of  red tape and bureaucracy .
Pay is dismal compared to Industry. No bonuses. If we get 2% inflation raise every year, we are lucky

review_title: This is really a place where academic professional guys should come, study and work.
pros: The professors' attitude of about academic are impressive. Most of them really want to do something creative, brilliant and practical.
cons: The city that the university settled in may be a drawback factor for quick and further development to it, even though it's always true that university should be the engine who starts and keeps the city running faster and more smoothly.

pros: International environment; friendly people; comprehensive subjects range; campus feeling;  a bunch of activities; responsible staffs; a good world-view through those events and workshops.

review_title: SUNY Buffalo is a strong institution.
pros:

-Buffalo is a friendly city.
-The university is well-organized, for the most part.
cons:
-The city of Buffalo is on the decline.
-Weather is obviously not a major attraction.
-Absolutely 0 school spirit.

review_title: Provider of a quality education at an exceptional price....with faculty and staff that truly want to help students.
pros: People care about what they do and are passionate about helping students.  Education is the heart of what we do and that is a main focus of the university.  It is about research and helping the community and world at large...with discoveries, better practices, etc.  But education is still the focus.
cons: Limited opportunities to gain supervisory experience.  Easy to get experience managing projects.

cons:
Work load can be demanding on top of schoolwork during exam time
You work for the State, and are automatically enrolled in a union

review_title: This is great and nice place to work and study with!

cons: The most important thing i have learned from this position is I have to do independent study and self-learning at most of time when i encounter the challenge and difficulty

job_title: Postdoctoral Research Associate in Buffalo, NY

cons: As a T.A., you make little money. As an adjunct, even less. God help you if you want dental care or have children.

review_title: It's a decent place to do phd.

cons: Winter is terrible with temperature drop to 20 F, and some times snow accumulates to 9 inch, the road turns to quite slippy, which make travelling uncomfortable.

pros: THe job is very stable, and the working pace is relatively slow. School is good and people are more willing to cooperate.
cons: less compensation. It is not a long-term job. Over the yeae, your salary is still pretty much the same, and can not even keep up with inflation.

pros: I work at the UB dining. The pay is pretty decent and I really enjoy working there. It is a positive environment.

pros: Great benefits, some flexibility in hours, intelligent group of people.  This place is a really good community of teachers and learners growing together.  The students are hard workers and very capable.

cons: The weather is pretty cold during winters in Buffalo, so if you don't have a car it can be a headache to get to work in the morning given the snow filled roads and extremely chilling air.

pros:

pros:

review_title: A great place to start, continue and complete a career.

review_title: As a full-time student, the flexibility associated with being a Graduate Assistant is ideal.

review_title: A great university to work for....

Work/life balance

large school with some diversity among  students(international students)
high potential for growth/advancement
